page.lettertext:
fol.210r
10 Augusti
1590
Our answer to the
states
uppon the l
re
from the states
befores sett downe
Uppon a l
re
from the States gen
r
all addressed unto us at the
Hague
dated the 18
th
of Auguste after the new style, and receaved by the
handes of
Remet
their Agent, wherby they requyred to be resolved
from us, of certen doubt
conceyved by the Provinc
(as they pretended)
abowt the Articles and condic
o
ns deli
v
ed unto them in wrytinge conc
r
ninge
their trade to
Spayne
Portingal
&c: we resorted to the Assembly of
the said States the xx
th
accordinge to the same Style, to gyve them answere to the poynt
of their l
re
by speeche: and first signified
unto them that we had receyved their saide l
re
, and desired to understand
the cawses that mighte move the Provinc
to demaunde the questions
mentioned in their l
re
unto us: The States requyred the l
re
might
be reade, w
ch
done the y declared that the Provinc
in respecte of
di
v
s difficultyes by them conceyved, desyred to knowe o
r
answeres to
the sev
r
all poynt
menc
oe
d in their l
re
, and prayed they mighte
receyve them from us in wrytinge: we answered that by speech wee
were contented to deli
v
as much as they requyred, but to
ceade any
further w
th
them in wrytinge untill wee mighte see more reason then
was alleaged to induce us thereunto, consideringe how much we had
allready deli
v
ed (to lyttle purpose as we conceyved) and how captiously
and suspiciouslye they had hetherto dealte w
th
us, we could not,
wishinge them therfore to satisfye themselves w
th
o
r
verbale answere.
Then, entringe into the matter wee shewed, that the condic
o
ns by us
exhibited, were w
th
her
Ma
t
knowledge conceyved, and sett downe by
the LL
: of her
privye Counsell
, in such shorte as her Ma
tie
intended
to have them observed by the Provinc
strictlye for the victuell &
munition, but for the other poynt
if they were such as the Provinc
w
th
owt theyr greater prejudice might not accomplishe, we thought
her Ma
tie
upon consderac
o
n had of the causes and reasons deli
v
ed,
mighte and woulde be induced to alter or inlarge them as should
seeme best unto her and her counsell, w
th
reguard to the State of
her owne kingdomes, and the good of these Provinc
. The States
sisted in their request, that o
r
answere such as it was, might be
deli
v
ed in wrytinge, for that it was an usuall course amonge
them allwayes to treate and negotiate by wrytinge, as answered
that it was contrary to the manner of
England
, and did
but increase confusion and lengthe in their
ceading
here,
and that o
r
worde in that place shoulde be as sufficient as o
r
wrytinge and therfore we requyred to be pardoned for
o
r
our
refusall./
Tho: Wylkes
Tho. Bodley
